Notes: On 1st December the Premier remarked that If there is a confirmed positive case within a public school in-person learning, at that school, be suspended immediately. https://archive.st/archive/2020/12/www.gov.bm/51js/www.gov.bm/articles/covid-19-update-%E2%80%93-premier%E2%80%99s-remarks-1-december-2020.html

School – CedarBridge Academy – closed until further notice to due to confirmed positive covid-19 case as per new protocol announced  1st December. http://web.archive.org/web/20201214235030/https://www.gov.bm/articles/ministry-education-announce-covid-19-developments-cedarbridge-academy

The Ministry of Health is advising that, as of today (December 5, 2020), bars and clubs are now required to close at midnight, rather than 2am as was previously permitted. http://web.archive.org/web/20201214235335/https://www.gov.bm/articles/covid-19-update-bars-and-clubs-5-december-2020
Indoor Bars and Nightclubs are closed as of 8th December http://web.archive.org/web/20201214230002/https://www.gov.bm/coronavirus-recreation
Existing outdoor bars are permitted to operate with table service only until 10p.m as of 12th December. http://web.archive.org/web/20201214230412/https://www.gov.bm/nightclubs-and-bars-guidance

Live performances are permitted, including drama, comedy and music, however, it’s very important that strict precautions are taken to ensure that everyone is protected from potential spread of the virus. http://web.archive.org/web/20201214230412/https://www.gov.bm/nightclubs-and-bars-guidance

Due to health and safety concerns, a decision was made to reduce the group gathering size from 75 persons, back to 50 persons. http://web.archive.org/web/20201214234628/https://www.gov.bm/articles/covid-regulations-compliance

The maximum permitted number of people in any group will be reduced further to ten. http://web.archive.org/web/20201215001740/https://www.gov.bm/articles/ministerial-statement-covid-19-%E2%80%93-need-further-action

On 11th December 2020, The Department of Public Transportation (DPT) advised the public that the public bus service will be suspended until further notice pending advice from the Ministry of Health.   The DPT announced that one (1) member of staff has tested positive for COVID-19. The department is liaising with the Epidemiology and Surveillance Unit for guidance. Out of an abundance of caution and to ensure the safety of others, the decision has been made to suspend the public bus service until an assessment from the Ministry of Health is completed.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201215000417/https://www.gov.bm/articles/public-bus-service-suspended-until-further-notice

Effective from 12th December a curfew will be in effect from 11pm until 6am daily. http://web.archive.org/web/20201215001740/https://www.gov.bm/articles/ministerial-statement-covid-19-%E2%80%93-need-further-action

As of this Friday, December 4th, a pre-arrival test must be taken within five days before arriving in Bermuda. All travellers – including returning students – are subject to mobile quarantine restrictions on their movements and activities, until they receive a negative Day 14 COVID-19 test result. http://web.archive.org/web/20201214232216/https://www.gov.bm/articles/covid-19-update-minister-health-remarks-1-december-2020     The Ministry developed ‘mobile quarantine’ as a means by which newly arriving travellers could be ‘free to roam’ if they had both a negative pre-arrival test and a negative test on arrival at the airport. The “Ten Tips for Mobile Quarantine During COVID-19” states, for example, that travellers cannot attend events with large groups of people, they must stay away from crowded places and they need to exercise outside and not in a gym or with a sports team. As part of mobile quarantine, all travellers are required to be tested on Day 4, Day 8 and Day 14 of their stay. If a traveller does not have a negative pre-arrival test, that person has to quarantine until a Day 8 negative test result. http://web.archive.org/web/20201214234331/https://www.gov.bm/articles/ministerial-statement-update-covid-19-public-health-guidance-december-2020

On 11th December, The Minister of Finance, the Hon Curtis L. Dickinson, authorised unemployment benefit payments to individuals whose ability to earn an income has been directly impacted by the recent measures the government has taken to reduce the spread of COVID-19. These benefit payments pertain to verified full-time employees of bars and nightclubs who have had to close due to current COVID-19 restrictions. The total benefit for these persons will be $1,000 for the two week period that these restrictions are in place. http://web.archive.org/web/20201215002252/https://www.gov.bm/articles/unemployment-benefits-11-december-2020

Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) Latest Updates - http://web.archive.org/web/20201215011545/https://www.gov.bm/coronavirus     WeHealth - Bermuda’s New COVID-19 Exposure Notification App - http://web.archive.org/web/20201215011705/https://www.gov.bm/wehealth-bermuda

On 1st December 2020, the health minister announced that they have amended health regulations so that it is now an offence to not wear a mask in accordance with the guidelines. A person who fails to wear a mask when one is required commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to—(a)   a fine of $500, in respect of a first offence; (b)   a fine of $1,000, for a second or subsequent offence. http://web.archive.org/web/20201214232216/https://www.gov.bm/articles/covid-19-update-minister-health-remarks-1-december-2020

Bermuda has two sources for procuring vaccines against COVID-19.  Bermuda will be supplied with 9,000 doses of the Pfizer vaccine and they will arrive on our shores in the first week of January 2021.   The second vaccine source is through Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance Geneva, which is administering the COVID-19 Vaccine Global Access Facility (the “COVAX Facility”). Bermuda has joined the COVAX Facility, and has purchased enough doses to cover 20% of our population. The leading vaccines likely to be received by Bermuda are those by AstraZeneca and Moderna. The timeframe for receipt of these vaccines through the COVAX Facility is not yet settled.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201215000755/https://www.gov.bm/articles/ministerial-statement-covid-19-vaccine-bermuda

Effective 30 November, the Province of Alberta moved all grade 7-12 students to at-home learning. In-person classes will resume 11 January after an extended winter break.  See Province of Alberta website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201125213917/https://www.alberta.ca/k-to-12-school-re-entry-2020-21-school-year.aspx

Effective 2 December, the Territory of Nunavut reopened elementary schools in some communities and reopened middle and secondary schools on some days with online learning on other days. In some communities, schools will on staggered schedules for elementary and secondary grades. The Arctic College in the capital city Iqaluit reopened for reduced numbers of students. Schools in Arviat remain closed. See Canadian Broadcasting Corporation website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201202192028/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/nunavut-government-gives-update-on-covid-19-response-1.5821820

Effective 14 December, publicly-funded elementary and secondary schools in the Province of Saskatchewan switched to online learning until at least 11 January. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201214232830/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-public-schools-in-regina-switch-to-remote-learning-as-covid-19-cases/

Although not as comprehensive as Nunavut’s lockdown, effective 27 November, the Province of Alberta imposed restricted access to some businesses in the two largest cities of Calgary and Edmonton as well as other districts designated as “purple zones” with a high incidence of covid-19 cases. See Province of Alberta website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201125215936/https://www.alberta.ca/enhanced-public-health-measures.aspx  Although not as stringent as Nunavut’s lockdown, effective 27 November, the Province of Saskatchewan enforced restricted access to restaurant seating and large retail stores. See Province of Saskatchewan website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201126003802/https://www.saskatchewan.ca/government/news-and-media/2020/november/25/covid-19-update-new-measures-in-effect-november-27

Effective 2 December, the Territory of Nunavut allowed some businesses and workplaces in some communities to reopen with physical distancing. Arviat remains under lockdown rules. See Canadian Broadcasting Corporation website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201202192028/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/nunavut-government-gives-update-on-covid-19-response-1.5821820

On 4 December, the Province of Nova Scotia extended the order through at least 16 December in Hants County and the capital Halifax region restricting restaurants and bars to take-out and delivery service, limiting retail stores to 25% of capacity and closing fitness centres, casinos and museums. See Province of Nova Scotia websites, archived:    https://web.archive.org/web/20201204210757/https://novascotia.ca/news/release/?id=20201204004   https://web.archive.org/web/20201204205944/https://novascotia.ca/coronavirus/county-restrictions/halifax/  Interesting article in the 4 December issue of the Globe and Mail newspaper pointing out that the provinces of Ontario and Quebec are now relying on inspections of construction, warehouse and manufacturing sites in contrast to closure orders or other more restrictive measures from March to the summer re-opening. See Globe and Mail website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201204170232/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-quebec-see-covid-19-outbreaks-at-workplaces-climb/

Although not as restrictive as in some Canadian jurisdictions, effective 7 December, the province of Prince Edward Island (PEI) closed all recreational and fitness facilities, casinos, bingo halls and other gaming establishments as well as museums and libraries; restricted restaurants and bars to take-out and delivery; and imposed a 50% capacity limit on retail stores. See government of PEI website, archived  https://web.archive.org/web/20201207125737/https://www.princeedwardisland.ca/en/information/health-and-wellness/pei-covid-19-circuit-breaker-december-2020

Effective Dec. 13, working from home is mandatory in the Province of Alberta when physical presence is not required. Restaurants and bars are restricted to take-out service. Retail outlets are restricted to the lesser of 15% of firecode capacity or 5 customers. All entertainment businesses and entities as well as personal and wellness services must close. See Government of Alberta website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201211114009/https://www.alberta.ca/release.cfm?xID=75859ADEA5D5E-045D-2386-0CB140C175A800DD

Effective 14 December, the Province of Ontario issued the following orders for the Windsor-Essex region (neighbouring Detroit, Michigan) and York region (suburban Toronto): retail stores must close for indoor shopping except those that sell groceries, drugs or hardware, which must respect a 50-per-cent capacity limit; restaurants restricted to takeout or delivery; gyms and hair salons must close. This order brings these regions in line with Toronto and the suburban Peel region. The York region member of the provincial Parliament expressed her disagreement with how the order applies to the retail sector. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201219193748/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-moves-two-more-regions-into-lockdown-in-bid-to-contain-covid/

Although not as restrictive as in some provinces, effective 19 December, the Province of Saskatchewan ordered casinos and other gaming houses to close and restricted personal care service establishments such as hair salons to 50 per cent capacity. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201219200259/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-saskatchewan-bans-household-visits-will-limit-retail-capacity-starting/?+First+Canadians+vaccinated+against+COVID-19+=&cu_id=A6KwM2NPqY9Tjy01oPJvjyThBi3rn%2FLU

Effective 21 December, the Province of Ontario issued the following orders for the Hamilton region (west of Toronto): retail stores must close for indoor shopping except those that sell groceries, drugs or hardware, which must respect a 50-per-cent capacity limit; restaurants restricted to takeout or delivery; gyms and hair salons must close. This order brings Hamilton in line with the City of Toronto and suburban regions as well as Windsor-Essex (neighbouring Detroit). See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221203858/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-updates-dec-19-vaccinations-now-underway-in-all-provinces/?cu_id=A6KwM2NPqY9Tjy01oPJvjyThBi3rn%2FLU

Although not as restrictive as some other provinces, effective 27 November, the Province of Saskatchewan restricted capacity to 30 people at all cultural, athletic, religious and gambling venues. Food or beverage service must be cordoned off from the activity area. See Province of Saskatchewan website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201126003802/https://www.saskatchewan.ca/government/news-and-media/2020/november/25/covid-19-update-new-measures-in-effect-november-27  Although not as restrictive as some other provinces, effective 27 November, the Province of New Brunswick limited regularly scheduled in-person religious services, cinema and live performances to 50 participants with two metres of physical distancing and weddings and funerals to 25 in the Fredericton capital zone. See Province of New Brunswick website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201127150930/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/news/news_release.2020.11.0640.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20201127152622/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/corporate/promo/covid-19/recovery.html

Effective 2 December, the Territory of Nunavut allowed arenas in some regions to reopen with a limit of 50 spectators. Arenas in some communities remain closed. See Canadian Broadcasting Corporation website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201202192028/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/nunavut-government-gives-update-on-covid-19-response-1.5821820

On 4 December, the Province of Nova Scotia extended the order through at least 16 December in Hants County and the capital Halifax region banning public events and festivals (sports, arts and culture). See Province of Nova Scotia websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201204210757/https://novascotia.ca/news/release/?id=20201204004   https://web.archive.org/web/20201204205944/https://novascotia.ca/coronavirus/county-restrictions/halifax/

Effective 7 December, the province of Prince Edward Island (PEI) banned organized sport and restricted religious, funeral and wedding services to 10 persons plus presiding officials. See government of PEI website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201207125737/https://www.princeedwardisland.ca/en/information/health-and-wellness/pei-covid-19-circuit-breaker-december-2020

Although not as restrictive as other provinces, effective 27 November, the Province of Saskatchewan limited indoor banquets, conferences, wedding and funeral receptions in public venues to 30 people.  Food or beverages may not be present or served. The maximum size for private gatherings in the home setting remains at five (except for families larger than five who cannot host anyone outside the immediate family). See Province of Saskatchewan website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201126003802/https://www.saskatchewan.ca/government/news-and-media/2020/november/25/covid-19-update-new-measures-in-effect-november-27  Although not as restrictive as some other provinces, effective 27 November, the Province of New Brunswick restricted outdoor gatherings in the Fredericton capital zone to 25 people or fewer with physical distancing also required. See Province of New Brunswick website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201127150930/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/news/news_release.2020.11.0640.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20201127152622/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/corporate/promo/covid-19/recovery.html

Effective 2 December, the Territory of Nunavut relaxed the limit on indoor gatherings to the household plus 10 or 15 people (depending on the region). Outdoor gatherings can be up to 50 people.  Arviat remains under lockdown rules. See Canadian Broadcasting Corporation website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201202192028/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/nunavut-government-gives-update-on-covid-19-response-1.5821820

On 4 December, the Province of Nova Scotia extended through at least 16 December in Hants County and the capital Halifax region the order limiting indoor and outdoor gatherings to the larger of 5 persons or the number of persons in a household. See Province of Nova Scotia websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201204210757/https://novascotia.ca/news/release/?id=20201204004   https://web.archive.org/web/20201204205944/https://novascotia.ca/coronavirus/county-restrictions/halifax/

Effective 7 December, the province of Prince Edward Island (PEI) restricted indoor and outdoor gatherings to 10 persons. See government of PEI website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201207125737/https://www.princeedwardisland.ca/en/information/health-and-wellness/pei-covid-19-circuit-breaker-december-2020

Effective 8 December, the Province of Alberta prohibited all indoor and outdoor social gatherings and limited close contacts to within each household except for persons living alone restricted to 2 in-person visitors who must always be the same 2. See Government of Alberta website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201211114009/https://www.alberta.ca/release.cfm?xID=75859ADEA5D5E-045D-2386-0CB140C175A800DD

Effective 17 December, the Province of Saskatchewan restricted outdoor gatherings to 10 people and indoor gatherings to immediate household members. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201219200259/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-saskatchewan-bans-household-visits-will-limit-retail-capacity-starting/?+First+Canadians+vaccinated+against+COVID-19+=&cu_id=A6KwM2NPqY9Tjy01oPJvjyThBi3rn%2FLU

Although not as prescriptive as some Canadian jurisdictions, effective 7 December, the province of Prince Edward Island (PEI) asked residents to work and shop from home whenever possible. See government of PEI website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201207125737/https://www.princeedwardisland.ca/en/information/health-and-wellness/pei-covid-19-circuit-breaker-december-2020

Effective 27 November, people travelling into New Brunswick, including from the other Atlantic provinces, are required to self-isolate for 14 days unless exempt. Registration for travel into New Brunswick is also now mandatory, including New Brunswickers returning home. Failure to register can result in penalties. See Province of New Brunswick website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201127150930/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/news/news_release.2020.11.0640.html

Effective 2 December, the Territory of Nunavut allowed travel to Rankin Inlet and Whale Cove, although non-essential travel is not recommended. Travel in and out of Arviat remains restricted. See Canadian Broadcasting Corporation website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201202192028/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/nunavut-government-gives-update-on-covid-19-response-1.5821820

On 29 November, federal Ministers announced that the ban on non-essential travel to Canada from countries other than the United States (US) and that the Mandatory Isolation Order for 14 days applying to essential travelers and Canadians returning from countries other than the US would be extended until 21 January 2021. These same measures continue to apply to travel from the US until 21 December 2020 and may be extended by a further month. Beginning 21 January 2021, Canada may be in a position to align extension dates for policies applying to travel from the US and from countries other than the US.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201130192516/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-safety-canada/news/2020/11/government-of-canada-announces-extension-of-travel-restrictions.html

Effective 21 December, the Government of Canada suspended flights from the United Kingdom from landing in Canada through at least 23 December while Canada “working with international partners, including the World Health Organization, (works) to better understand …. the genetic variant of the virus that causes COVID-19 … identified in the United Kingdom”. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221150238/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/news/2020/12/canada-suspends-flights-from-the-united-kingdom-for-72-hours.html

On 30 November, the federal Minister of Finance announced “increasing the maximum rate of the Canada Emergency Wage Subsidy to 75 per cent for the period beginning December 20, 2020 and extending this rate until March 13, 2021” https://web.archive.org/web/20201130213318/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/news/2020/11/government-of-canada-releases-supporting-canadians-and-fighting-covid-19-fall-economic-statement-2020.html

On 17 December, Statistics Canada released data showing that a record high 1.2 million Canadians received Employment Insurance (EI) benefits for unemployment in October. Together with self-employed Canada Recovery Benefit (CRB) recipients and other CRB recipients not eligible for EI, over 2 million Canadians (or over 10% of the pre-pandemic labour force) were receiving a job-related income support benefit from the federal government in October.   See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221195204/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/business/article-canadians-on-ei-surges-to-record-in-october-after-cerb-transfer/?cu_id=A6KwM2NPqY9Tjy01oPJvjyThBi3rn%2FLU

Effective 20 December, the federal Minister of Finance “announced that the government has concluded the necessary regulatory changes to raise the maximum (Canada Emergency) Wage Subsidy rate to 75 per cent” until 13 March 2021. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221151917/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/news/2020/12/government-announces-wage-subsidy-rate-increase-to-75-per-cent.html

On 30 November, the federal Minister of Finance announced “extending the current rates of the Canada Emergency Rent Subsidy and Lockdown Support until March 13, 2021” for businesses.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201130213318/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/news/2020/11/government-of-canada-releases-supporting-canadians-and-fighting-covid-19-fall-economic-statement-2020.html

On 4 December, the Province of Nova Scotia announced easier access to testing to asymptomatic persons and recommended testing for those aged 16 to 35 and all those who have attended social gatherings without proper distancing in the past 14 days. See Province of Nova Scotia websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201204210757/https://novascotia.ca/news/release/?id=20201204004

On 18 December, the Globe and Mail, Canada’s only national newspaper with a national readership, reported that “(s)ince the start of the second wave, test and tracing regimes in the hardest-hit provinces like Alberta, Ontario and Quebec were curtailed after becoming overloaded. Data on the location of outbreaks, which were limited to start, became even less reliable.” See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221200749/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-tam-calls-for-stricter-covid-19-lockdown-measures-in-hard-hit/

Effective 27 November, the Province of Saskatchewan extended mandatory mask wearing to all prisons, indoor fitness centres (except aquatic activities), students ages 3-12, and workers and visitors in all workplace and commercial common areas. See Province of Saskatchewan website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201126003802/https://www.saskatchewan.ca/government/news-and-media/2020/november/25/covid-19-update-new-measures-in-effect-november-27

Effective 1 December, the Yukon Territory made it mandatory for all persons over the age of two (with very limited exceptions) to wear a mask in all indoor public spaces.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201125070821/https://yukon.ca/en/news/november-24-2020-covid-19-update

On 4 December, Nova Scotia’s Chief Medical Officer of Health repeated his recommendation that all residents “wear a mask in indoor public places”. See Province of Nova Scotia websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201204210757/https://novascotia.ca/news/release/?id=20201204004

Effective 8 December, the Province of Alberta extended the mask requirement in indoor public spaces to the entire province. See Government of Alberta website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201211114009/https://www.alberta.ca/release.cfm?xID=75859ADEA5D5E-045D-2386-0CB140C175A800DD

On 9 December, Health Canada approved Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine “for use in people 16 years of age or older”. “Canada will receive up to 249,000 doses” later this month. The federal government is arranging distribution to provincial governments with the first group of high-priority recipients expected to receive vaccinations before year end. See Government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201210205358/https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/news/2020/12/health-canada-authorizes-first-covid-19-vaccine0.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20201210210347/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-services-procurement/news/2020/12/canada-to-receive-early-delivery-of-pfizer-biontech-covid-19-vaccine.html

On 10 December, Prime Minister Trudeau repeated the Government of Canada’s commitment that the covid-19 “vaccine would be completely free for all Canadians”. See Global News website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201216164929/https://globalnews.ca/news/7514966/coronavirus-canada-vaccine-rollout-trudeau/

On 14 December, Ontario began vaccinating health care workers in Toronto and Quebec vaccinated workers and residents at long-term care facilities in Montreal and Quebec City. Other provinces are expected to start targeted vaccinations of high-risk groups later this week. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201216165500/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-canada-administers-its-first-covid-19-vaccine-shots/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201214190242/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-personal-support-worker-first-person-in-canada-to-receive-dose/

On 15 December, British Columbia, Alberta, and Saskatchewan began vaccinating front-line health care workers.  See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201219203531/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/british-columbia/article-western-canada-long-complex-job-of-covid-19-vaccinations-begins/

On 16 December, Nova Scotia, Newfoundland and Labrador, Prince Edward Island, and Manitoba began vaccinating front-line health care workers.  See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201219202229/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-manitoba-three-atlantic-provinces-to-begin-covid-19-vaccinations-today/

On 19 December, the Canadian Press news service reported that the Province of New Brunswick began vaccinations starting with front-line health care workers and long-term care residents. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221203858/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-updates-dec-19-vaccinations-now-underway-in-all-provinces/?cu_id=A6KwM2NPqY9Tjy01oPJvjyThBi3rn%2FLU

Many school districts and universities returned to all-remote learning for the remainder the 2020 academic calendar instead of returning to in-person instruction after the Thanksgiving holiday. Examples include Tulsa, Oklahoma school districts and Arkansas Springdale School District.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201022013733/https://www.tulsaschools.org/about/news/news-item/~board/district-news/post/update-on-quarter-two-modes-of-learning  https://web.archive.org/web/20201128152223/https://www.nwahomepage.com/back-to-class/list-tracking-schools-with-covid-19-cases/    Universities have also announced extended winter breaks and canceled Spring Breaks to control COVID-19 on campus and among students and staff. Examples include the University of Oklahoma and the Oklahoma State University, which both announce they will extend winter break by one week and cancel Spring Break 2021     https://web.archive.org/web/20201123075018/https://www.ou.edu/web/news_events/articles/news_2020/ou-announces-calendar-updates-to-fall-spring-semesters  https://web.archive.org/web/20201123075128/https://go.okstate.edu/coronavirus/latest-announcements/spring-start-date-2020.html    Many other universities have urged or required on-campus students to get tested before returning home for the Thanksgiving holiday. University responses vary greatly.  Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201130235220/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/09/us/colleges-coronavirus-thanksgiving.html

All levels of education are closed in Puerto Rico and the District of Columbia, as well as in some parts of other states like California, New York, and Hawaii.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201213015256/https://www.edweek.org/leadership/map-where-are-schools-closed/2020/07

Full closure at all levels of education is still in effect in Puerto Rico and District of Columbia. There is also partial closure still in effect in other states including California, Delaware, West Virginia, Hawaii, New York, New Mexico, North Carolina, Michigan, Kentucky, Oregon etc.    https://archive.vn/aqPu5

Several states have rolled back restrictions on business after Thanksgiving holidays, so I’m changing the code to a 2T.     New Mexico transitioned from shutting down all essential businesses to a coding system whereby counties can reopen starting December 2.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201205192217/https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/120220-PHO.pdf     In Arizona, businesses can operate at a limited capacity if certain benchmarks are met.     In California, some businesses such as movie theaters and bars are closed. However, other industries such as retail stores can operate at 20% capacity.     In Georgia, gyms, hair salons and movies can operate, with restrictions.     In Idaho and Oregon, businesses can be open but are encouraged to telework when possible.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201205191446/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html

High-risk sectors like gyms and bars are closed in some states (e.g. California, Kansas)    https://web.archive.org/web/20201213021746/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html

High risk sectors such as nightclubs, private clubs, bowling alleys, theaters etc remain closed in some states such as Pennsylvania, Michigan etc     Sources :  http://web.archive.org/web/20201221162235/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html      Michigan - http://web.archive.org/web/20201221181943/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/     Pennsylvania - http://web.archive.org/web/20201221185142/https://www.pa.gov/guides/responding-to-covid-19/

Several states, such as Illinois, are now cancelling public events.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201213023613/https://www.northstarmeetingsgroup.com/News/Industry/Coronavirus-states-cities-reopening-COVID-19-new-cases

Several states such as Illinois and California have strict limitations on social gatherings.     In Illinois, Executive Order 2020-73 limited outdoor gatherings to no more than 10 people and recommended social distancing at all times.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201130122507/https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2020-73.aspx    All public and private gatherings with individuals not in one's household are prohibited, except for faith based services and protests in Los Angeles, California.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201130084341/http://www.publichealth.lacounty.gov/phcommon/public/media/mediapubhpdetail.cfm?prid=2830

In Oregon, gatherings are now restricted to six people or fewer.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201213023613/https://www.northstarmeetingsgroup.com/News/Industry/Coronavirus-states-cities-reopening-COVID-19-new-cases

Some states such as Virginia and Illinois have limited indoor and outdoor gatherings to no more than 10 people.  Sources:  Virginia - http://web.archive.org/web/20201221014328/https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/governor-of-virginia/pdf/Forward-Virginia-Phase-Three-Guidelines-December-2020.pdf   Illinois - https://archive.vn/xwXFb
Across the country, public transport is operating but at reduced capacity.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201123194911/https://time.com/5869375/public-transit-coronavirus-covid/
No Policy change.

Regional stay at home orders are in effect in California.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201213021746/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html

The Regional Stay Home Order, announced in California on December 3, 2020 is still in effect. https://archive.vn/aX3BT  Also other states such as North Carolina etc. mandated curfews - http://web.archive.org/web/20201221231005/https://www.nc.gov/covid-19/staying-ahead-curve

New York now requires all visitors from non-contiguous states to self-isolate or provide evidence of a test.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201213024100/https://coronavirus.health.ny.gov/covid-19-travel-advisory#:~:text=For%2520travelers%2520who%2520were%2520out,must%2520obtain%2520another%2520COVID%2520test.

Traveler/visitors to and residents of New Hampshire need to self-quarantine for 10 days following the last date of any travel domestically outside the surrounding new England states. http://web.archive.org/web/20201221232912/https://www.covidguidance.nh.gov/out-state-visitors     Out-of-state travelers arriving in New York who want to opt out of a 14-day quarantine requirement must get tested within three days before arriving, quarantine for three days upon arrival and get tested again on day four. Both tests must be negative to avoid a 14-day quarantine. Essential workers and travelers from bordering states are exempt.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201221233311/https://coronavirus.health.ny.gov/covid-19-travel-advisory     All out-of-state travelers coming into Maine, and Maine residents returning to Maine, must either receive a negative COVID-19 test within 72 hours prior to arrival or complete a 10-day quarantine.  https://archive.vn/FeGA4
Travelers from certain countries are prohibited from the United States.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201213024449/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
Travelers from certain countries ( e.g. China, Iran, United Kingdom etc.)are prohibited from Entry into the US - specific exemptions may apply. https://archive.vn/Oh89R

Lawmakers struck a nearly $900 billion COVID-19 stimulus deal Sunday 20th December that includes another round of stimulus checks and jobless benefits for Americans. The deal includes restarting a $300 boost to the federal unemployment insurance benefit, extending eviction moratoriums for renters by a month and a $600 direct payment to most Americans. http://web.archive.org/web/20201222002401if_/https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/2020/12/20/stimulus-checks-unemployment-benefits-economy-covid-relief-package/3921356001/     http://web.archive.org/web/20201222002909/https://edition.cnn.com/2020/12/20/politics/stimulus-latest-shutdown-deadline/index.html

Temporary halt in residential eviction is still in effect until December 31st. http://web.archive.org/web/20201221123939/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/downloads/eviction-moratoria-order-faqs.pdf
No change
Coordinated Public Campaign by CDC is still ongoing.

In some states testing is generally available. In Arizona, for instance, test providers accept most insurance and do not require symptoms.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201213024848/https://www.maricopa.gov/5588/COVID-19-Testing

On the 15th December, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration issued an emergency use authorization (EUA) for the first over-the-counter (OTC) fully at-home diagnostic test for COVID-19. The Ellume COVID-19 Home Test is a rapid, lateral flow antigen test, a type of test that runs a liquid sample along a surface with reactive molecules. The test detects fragments of proteins of the SARS-CoV-2 virus from a nasal swab sample from any individual 2 years of age or older.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201221163814/https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/coronavirus-covid-19-update-fda-authorizes-antigen-test-first-over-counter-fully-home-diagnostic
No Policy change

Maska are required at all times outside the home in Nevada.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201213025115/https://www.cnn.com/2020/06/19/us/states-face-mask-coronavirus-trnd/index.html
Masks are mandatory at all times in Nevada etc.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201221162235/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html

No vaccines have yet been distributed, but vaccination is imminent. Details of distribution will be in the hands of states.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201213025730/https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/12/what-we-know-about-u-s-covid-19-vaccine-distribution-plan.html

First Covid-19 vaccines in US were administered on 14th December 2020. High-risk health care workers are the first in line for inoculations.     New York - http://web.archive.org/web/20201222015252/https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2020/12/14/first-covid-vaccines-new-york/     Michigan - http://web.archive.org/web/20201222015925/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98158-547433--,00.html     According to the CDC Website - Because the supply of COVID-19 vaccine in the United States is expected to be limited at first, CDC recommends that initial supplies of COVID-19 vaccine be allocated to healthcare personnel and long-term care facility residents.  Hence, coded as Two groups. http://web.archive.org/web/20201222015702/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/recommendations.html     Code change from zero because according to Forbes, The federal government’s has ordered a total of 200 million doses so far from Moderna, which is enough to immunize 100 million Americans because the vaccine requires two shots. This is more than 20% of the population.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201222024503if_/https://www.forbes.com/sites/joewalsh/2020/12/11/us-ordered-100-million-extra-doses-of-modernas-covid-vaccine/?sh=1666247f3ef3

On the 18th of December, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration issued an emergency use authorization (EUA) for the second vaccine for the prevention of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). The emergency use authorization allows the Moderna COVID-19 Vaccine to be distributed in the U.S. for use in individuals 18 years of age and older.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201221163049/https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/fda-takes-additional-action-fight-against-covid-19-issuing-emergency-use-authorization-second-covid

According to the CDC website, as at 20th of December 2,838,225 doses had been distributed and 556,208 vaccines doses had been administered. Total doses distributed are cumulative counts of COVID-19 vaccine doses recorded as shipped in the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s (CDC) Vaccine Tracking System (VTrckS) since December 13, 2020.  Cumulative totals reflect data available as of 1:00 pm on the day of reporting. Total doses administered are cumulative counts of individual COVID-19 vaccine doses as reported to the CDC by state, territorial, and local public health agencies and five federal entities (Bureau of Prisons, Veterans Administration, Department of Defense, Department of State, and Indian Health Services) since December 14, 2020.  Cumulative doses administered reflect current data available as of 1:00 pm on the day of reporting.  Doses distributed and administered are for Pfizer BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine only at this time.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201221164321/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/index.html
